field_edited_text.value:
168 MARYLAND’S PRIMARY BRIDGE PROGRAM

Nice Highway, U. S. Route No. 40, completed from Baltimore to Havre de
Grace and scheduled for early completion from Havre de Grace to the
Delaware State Line.

The Patapsco River Bridge and approaches connect existing Baltimore
City Streets in Canton and Fairfield and this bridge would be accessible
without additional highway connections, by way of existing city streets
and county and state highways. A number of different connections are
shown on ‘“Vieinity Map’’ Plate 17 by means of which, together with this
crossing, the principal routes north from Baltimore would be connected with
the principal routes south from Baltimore. It is contemplated however
that entirely new highway connections will be constructed by the time this
bridge has been completed, which will connect the immediate approach
roadways directly with the Philadelphia Road at its intersection with -
Erdman Avenue and with the Baltimore-Washington Boulevard in the
vicinity of Elkridge. It is further contemplated that the bridge together
with these new approach highways will constitute a new high speed by-pass
of the City of Baltimore with traffic at all intersections controlled, and with
grades separated at all intersections with railroads and main thoroughfares.

The Potomac River Bridge will require the construction of approach high-
ways, in Maryland from La Plata to the bridge and in Virginia from Bowling
Green to the bridge.

Both Chesapeake Bay Bridges and the immediate approach roadways
must be considered in connection with additional approach highways.
Those required in connection with the Millers Island-Tolchester Bridge
include an entirely new highway from Tolchester to Centerville with a
new bridge over the Chester River, and relocation and reconstruction of
existing roads from Baltimore to Bay Shore. Additional approach highways
required in connection with the Chesapeake Bay Bridge from Sandy Point
to Kent Island include an entirely new highway from the vicinity of Jones
Station on the Governor Ritchie Highway to the western bridge approach
and an entirely new highway from the Vicinity of Stevensville on Route
No. 404 to the eastern bridge approach.

The traffic report submitted by Coverdale and Colpitts to the State Roads
Commission on September 3, 1938, presents estimates of gross revenue to
be derived from tolls at each of the crossings. Coverdale and Colpitts in
collaboration with J. E. Greiner Company have also estimated annual
maintenance, operation and insurance expenses for each of the crossings.
Estimates of cost of each of the crossings and approaches have been de-
veloped and presented hereinbefore.
